bibl.title: Transcript from the Court of Missing Heirs, Program No. 93, September 23, 1941

div1.p: This transcript focuses on the estate of Wallace Forbes and discusses the government pension due him and his heirs for his service as a volunteer in the Yellow Fever Commission experiments, in Cuba.

div1.head: Transcript from the Court of Missing Heirs, Program No. 93, September 23, 1941
div1.opener:
The COURT of MISSING HEIRS
RADIO PROGRAM
LOCK BOX 705 NEW YORK
Broadcast Tuesday, Sept. 23, 1941
_______________________
JAMES F. WATERS · Authors · ALFRED SHEBEL
_______________________
Review of Facts
Program No. 93
div1.p:
WALLACE WELLINGTON FORBES - WANTED ONLY FOR ONE REASON BY THE UNITED STATES ARMY
FINANCE DEPARTMENT TO GIVE HIM $17,750 and NO CHARGE WILL BE BROUGHT AGAINST WALLACE
W. FORBES AND HE SHOULD HAVE NO FEAR IN APPLYING FOR THIS MONEY.

Wallace Wellington Forbes is a missing heir actually to his own estate for the reason
that an Act of Congress passed on February 28, 1929 granted to six Spanish War
Veterans $125.00 a month for life as a reward for their heroism in submitting to tests
conducted by Major Walter Reed after the Spanish American War in Cuba in an effort to
stamp out the disease of Yellow Fever. Wallace Wellington Forbes was born in Gales-
burg, Illinois, the son of James Wellington Forbes and he enlisted for service in the
Spanish-American War in 1898, from Minneapolis where his parents were living at the
time. He lived in Minneapolis after his discharge from service in 1902 until 1916
when he reenlisted again to serve with Pershing's Punitive Expedition into Mexico. He
re-enlisted twice afterwards, but in 1926, at the Presidio he left the Army. Wallace
Wellington Forbes, the missing heir to his own estate will be paid $125.00 a month for
the balance of his life, as well as collecting the above accumulation of payments,
payable since 1929. The physical description of the missing heir is as follows: Light
blue eyes - blond hair - stocky build - long body and short legs - present age 62 years
- ruddy complexion - weight when last seen approximately 150 to 165 lbs.

Margaret Kenny was born Margaret Corrigan in County Cavan, Ireland. It appears from
the record that she was married near the city of Lynn, Massachusetts or the Charles-
town Section of Boston to Edward J. Kenny. After the marriage Margaret Kenny and her
husband took up their residence in San Francisco. When she died she left an estate
under terms of a Will bequeathing $4,000 as a legacy to her niece and nephew, whose
names are Grace and Henry Hawley. It is known that the missing heirs, Grace and Henry
Hawley, children of her sister, lived at Lynn, Mass. or in the Charlestown Section of
Boston. These two cities are the last known whereabouts of the missing heirs.

Earl Warren was accidentally killed in Quadio, Connecticut, in 1920, due to fatal
injuries received while being employed in a sawmill. At the time of his death he left
six children with varying ages up to eleven years. Two of these children are today
missing heirs who will divide equally the $1700.00 balance of a compensation award.
The names of the missing heirs are Walter Warren and Florence Warren. It is known
that Florence Warren was married and her married name was Mrs. George Zemek. She was
last heard of in Mansfield, Conn. where she was living with her foster-father, but it
is known that she came to New York City to live and may be living there today. The
physical description of Mrs. Florence Warren Zemek is as follows: brown eyes - light
brown hair - medium build - present age 21 years - light complexion - weight when last
seen 126 lbs. The second missing heir Walter Warren is 29 years of age, was honorably
discharged from the Army on Sept. 13, 1940. Walter Warren lived in Providence, R.I.
at different times and had the address of General Delivery in that city.

We trust this will give you the information you desire. May we take
this opportunity of thanking you for your interest as a listener to our program.
div1.closer:
THE COURT OF MISSING HEIRS
Radio Program
Look Box 705 New York The makers of Ironized Yeast will pay fifty dollars ($50.00) to the person from whom
the Court of Missing Heirs first receives information, which in the opinion of the
Administrators leads to the discovery of the heirs to any of the above cases.
The Court of Missing Heirs is not vested with judicial power, and is not a court of law or a part of the judicial system of any
state. Rather it is a dramatization of facts broadcast from coast to coast in an effort to find the heirs to estates unknown to them.--
The sole purpose of this court is to render a public service gratuitously--to enable missing heirs to secure the legacies that are
rightfully theirs. It is not the purpose of the court to give legal advice--and it does not solicit or accept compensation from anyone.
